block.p: Detroit's Big Three were not impressed today by Japan's announcement that it would reduce the number of cars it exports to the United States to 1.65 million a year, saying the Japanese are still not playing fair.
And the United States said it did not seek the cut in Japanese car exports. "It was the Japanese decision on their own," a White House official said.

Detroit's Big Three were not impressed today by Japan's announcement that it would reduce the number of cars it exports to the United States to 1.65 million a year, saying the Japanese are still not playing fair.
And the United States said it did not seek the cut in Japanese car exports. "It was the Japanese decision on their own," a White House official said.
"They give the misleading impression that something meaningful is being done to reduce the U.S. trade deficit with Japan," the General Motors Corporation said in a statement.

The chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Harold Poling, said, "All that has happened is that the Japanese Government has proposed a voluntary level for 1992 at about the same volume their auto makers imported into the United States from Japan in 1991."

The current ceiling is 2.3 million a year but sales are running at 1.76 million. The Chrysler Corporation said the quota should be slashed to one million vehicles a year to "get back to a level playing field for everybody.
